notes: Defender branding introduced 1990 for 90/110/130 models. Body-on-frame construction with permanent four-wheel drive. Td5 engine introduced 1998. Limited US availability (primarily grey market imports). Basic mechanical design with minimal electronics. Diesel timing belt service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Defender article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Range Rover final years (1970-1996). Body-on-frame construction with coil spring suspension. Features permanent four-wheel drive, optional air suspension (from 1992). Diesel available internationally. Vintage electronics and mechanical complexity. Timing chain V8 engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.5L I6 turbo diesel (136 hp BMW M51)
notes: Second-generation Range Rover (P38A). Body-on-frame construction with electronic air suspension standard. First Range Rover with electronic traction control (ETC). Features GEMS/Bosch engine management. BMW diesel engine. Complex air suspension and electronics notorious for reliability issues requiring specialized diagnostics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Freelander, marketed as LR1 in North America (2002-2005 only). Monocoque construction. Features Hill Descent Control, viscous coupling center differential. Timing belt I4 engine requires regular service. CVT transmission known for reliability issues. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Freelander article, January 2025 revision.

Discovery Series II (1999-2004) and late Series I models (1994-1998). Body-on-frame construction. Features Active Cornering Enhancement (ACE), Hill Descent Control. Diesel available internationally. Timing chain V8 engines. Transfer case and differential service critical for longevity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Discovery article, January 2025 revision.
